sub_topic: Probability of a certain weather event occurring
message_1: What is the probability that it will rain on exactly 3 days out of the next 10 days if the probability of rain each day is 0.4?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of exactly k successes (rainy days) in n trials (days)
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (also written as nCk or "n choose k")
- p is the probability of success (rain) on a single trial (day)
- n is the number of trials (days)
- k is the number of successes (rainy days)

In this case, we have:
- n = 10 (days)
- k = 3 (rainy days)
- p = 0.4 (probability of rain each day)

First, we need to calculate C(n, k), which is the number of ways to choose 3 rainy days out of 10 days:

C(10, 3) = 10! / (3! * (10-3)!)
          = 10! / (3! * 7!)
          = (10 * 9 * 8) / (3 * 2 * 1)
          = 120

Now we can plug these values into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 3) = C(10, 3) * 0.4^3 * (1-0.4)^(10-3)
         = 120 * 0.4^3 * 0.6^7
         = 120 * 0.064 * 0.0279936
         = 0.21504

So the probability that it will rain on exactly 3 days out of the next 10 days is approximately 0.215 or 21.5%.
